1. First note the coefficient of \(x^2\) in this case is \({@a1@}\). Multiply the whole expression by this number and rearrange as follows: 

    \[ {@a1@}({@a1@}x^2 + {@a1+1@}x + 1) = {@a1@}({@a1@}x^2) + {@a1@}({@a1+1@})x + {@a1@}(1) = ({@a1@}x)^2 + {@a1+1@}({@a1@}x)  + {@a1@}. \] 

    We now introduce a new variable \(z\) such that \(z = {@a1@}x\). Thus we can write 

    \[ ({@a1@}x)^2 + {@a1+1@}({@a1@}x)  + {@a1@} \text{ as } z^2 + {@a1+1@}z + {@a1@}. \] 

    This can be factorised to give \( (z + {@a1@})(z + 1)\). Returning to the original variable by replacing \(z\) by \({@a1@}x\) we find

     \[ {@a1@}({@a1@}x^2 + {@a1+1@}x + 1) = ({@a1@}x + {@a1@})({@a1@}x + 1) \] 

    A factor of \({@a1@}\) can be extracted from the first bracket on the right so that 

    \[ {@a1@}({@a1@}x^2 + {@a1+1@}x + 1)  = {@a1@}(x + 1)({@a1@}x + 1), \] 

    so that 

    \[ {@a1@}x^2 + {@a1+1@}x + 1 = ({@a1@}x + 1)(x + 1). \]

  2. First note the coefficient of \(x^2\) in this case is \({@b1@}\). Multiply the whole expression by this number and rearrange as follows: 

    \[ {@b1@}({@b1@}x^2 + {@b1*2@}x + {@b1@}) = {@b1@}({@b1@}x^2) + {@b1@}({@2*b1@})x + {@b1@}({@b1@}) = ({@b1@}x)^2 + {@2*b1@}({@b1@}x)  + {@b1*b1@}. \] 

    We now introduce a new variable \(z\) such that \(z = {@b1@}x\). Thus we can write 

    \[ ({@b1@}x)^2 + {@2*b1@}({@b1@}x)  + {@b1*b1@}. \text{ as } z^2 + {@2*b1@}z + {@b1*b1@}. \] 

    This can be factorised to give \( (z + {@b1@})(z + {@b1@})\). Returning to the original variable by replacing \(z\) by \({@b1@}x\) we find

     \[ {@b1@}({@b1@}x^2 + {@b1*2@}x + {@b1@}) = ({@b1@}x + {@b1@})({@b1@}x + {@b1@}) \] 

    A factor of \({@b1@}\) can be extracted from both of the brackets on the right so that 

    \[ {@b1@}({@b1@}x^2 + {@b1*2@}x + {@b1@})  = {@b1@}^2(x + 1)(x + 1), \] 

    so that 

    \[ {@b1@}x^2 + {@b1*2@}x + {@b1@} = {@b1@}(x + 1)(x + 1). \]


  3. First note the coefficient of \(x^2\) in this case is \({@c@}\). Multiply the whole expression by this number and rearrange as follows: 

    \[ {@c@}(3x^2 + {@3*(c1-c2)@}x - {@3*c1*c2@}) = {@c@}({@c@}x^2) + {@c@}({@3*(c1 - c2)@})x - {@c@}({@3*c1*c2@}) = ({@c@}x)^2 + {@3*(c1 - c2)@} ({@c@}x)  - {@c*3*c1*c2@}. \] 

    We now introduce a new variable \(z\) such that \(z = {@c@}x\). Thus we can write 

    \[ ({@c@}x)^2 + {@3*(c1 - c2)@} ({@c@}x)  - {@c*3*c1*c2@} \text{ as } z^2 +{@3*(c1 - c2)@} z - {@c*3*c1*c2@}. \] 

    This can be factorised to give \( (z + {@3*c1@})(z - {@3*c2@})\). Returning to the original variable by replacing \(z\) by \({@c@}x\) we find

     \[ {@c@}(3x^2 + {@3*(c1-c2)@}x - {@3*c1*c2@}) =  ({@c@}x + {@3*c1@})({@c@}x - {@3*c2@}) \] 

    A factor of \({@c@}\) can be extracted from both brackets on the right so that 

    \[ {@c@}(3x^2 + {@3*(c1-c2)@}x - {@3*c1*c2@})  = {@c^2@} (x + {@c1@})(x - {@c2@}), \] 

    so that 

    \[ 3x^2 + {@3*(c1-c2)@}x - {@3*c1*c2@} =  {@c@} (x + {@c1@})(x - {@c2@}). \]


  4. First note the coefficient of \(x^2\) in this case is \({@d1@}\). Multiply the whole expression by this number and rearrange as follows: 

    \[ {@d1@}({@d1@}x^2 - {@d1-1@}x -1) = {@d1@}({@d1@}x^2) - {@d1@}({@(d1 - 1)@})x - {@d1@}(1) = ({@d1@}x)^2 - {@d1 - 1 @} ({@d1@}x)  - {@d1@}. \] 

    We now introduce a new variable \(z\) such that \(z = {@d1@}x\). Thus we can write 

    \[ ({@d1@}x)^2 - {@d1 - 1 @} ({@d1@}x)  - {@d1@}. \text{ as } z^2 -{@d1 - 1 @} z - {@d1@}. \] 

    This can be factorised to give \( (z - {@d1@})(z + 1)\). Returning to the original variable by replacing \(z\) by \({@d1@}x\) we find

     \[ {@d1@}({@d1@}x^2 - {@d1-1@}x -1) = ({@d1@}x - {@d1@})({@d1@}x + 1) \] 

    A factor of \({@d1@}\) can be extracted from the first bracket on the right so that 

    \[ {@d1@}({@d1@}x^2 - {@d1-1@}x -1)  = {@d1@}(x - 1)({@d1@}x + 1), \] 

    so that 

    \[ {@d1@}x^2 - {@d1-1@}x -1 = (x - 1)({@d1@}x + 1). \]


  5. First note the coefficient of \(x^2\); in this case is \({@e1^2@}\). Multiply the whole expression by this number and rearrange as follows: 

    \[ {@e1^2@}({@e1^2@}x^2  -1) = {@e1^2@}({@e1^2@}x^2) - {@e1^2@}(1) = ({@e1^2@}x)^2   - {@e1^2@}. \] 

    We now introduce a new variable \(z\) such that \(z = {@e1^2@}x\) Thus we can write 

    \[  ({@e1^2@}x)^2   - {@e1^2@} \text{ as } z^2 - {@e1^2@}. \] 

    This can be factorised to give \( (z + {@e1@})(z - {@e1@})\). Returning to the original variable by replacing \(z\) by \({@e1^2@}x\) we find

     \[ {@e1^2@}({@e1^2@}x^2  -1) = ({@e1^2@}x + {@e1@})({@e1^2@}x - {@e1@}) \] 

    A factor of \({@e1@}\) can be extracted from both of the brackets on the right so that 

    \[ {@e1^2@}({@e1^2@}x^2  -1)  = {@e1^2@}({@e1@}x + 1)({@e1@}x - 1), \] 

    so that 

    \[ {@e1^2@}x^2  -1 = ({@e1@}x + 1)({@e1@}x - 1). \]


  6. First note the coefficient of \(x^2\); in this case is \(-1\). Multiply the whole expression by this number and rearrange as follows: 

    \[ -1(-x^2 + 1) = -1(-x^2)  -1(1) = x^2 - 1. \] 

    This can be factorised to give \( (x + 1)(x - 1)\). 

    Thus,

     \[ -(-x^2 + 1) = (x + 1)(x - 1) \] 

    A factor of \(-1\) can be extracted from the second bracket on the right so that 

    \[ -(-x^2 + 1)  =  -(x + 1)(1 - x), \] 

    so that 

    \[ -x^2 + 1 = (x + 1)(1 - x). \]



  7. First note the coefficient of \(x^2\) in this case is \(-{@g2@}\). Multiply the whole expression by this number and rearrange as follows: 

    \[ -{@g2@}(-{@g2@}x^2 + {@g1-g2@}x + {@g1@}) = -{@g2@}(-{@g2@}x^2) - {@g2@}({@g1-g2@})x - {@g2@}({@g1@}) = ({@g2@}x)^2 - {@g1-g2@}({@g2@}x) -  {@g2*g1@}. \] 

    We now introduce a new variable \(z\) such that \(z = {@g2@}x\). Thus we can write 

    \[  ({@g2@}x)^2 - {@g1-g2@}({@g2@}x) - {@g2*g1@} \text{ as } z^2 - {@g1-g2@}z - {@g2*g1@}. \] 

    This can be factorised to give \( (z - {@g1@})(z + {@g2@})\). Returning to the original variable by replacing \(z\) by \({@g2@}x\) we find

     \[ -{@g2@}(-{@g2@}x^2 + {@g1-g2@}x + {@g1@}) = ({@g2@}x - {@g1@})({@g2@}x + {@g2@}) \] 

    A factor of \({@g2@}\) can be extracted from the second bracket, and a factor of \(-1\) from the first bracket on the right so that 

    \[ -{@g2@}(-{@g2@}x^2 + {@g1-g2@}x + {@g1@})  = -{@g2@} (-{@g2@}x + {@g1@})(x + 1), \] 

    so that 

    \[ (-{@g2@}x^2 + {@g1-g2@}x + {@g1@}) =({@g1@} - {@g2@}x)(x + 1). \]
